Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Environmental Agencies and their Effective Monitoring of the Hydrocarbon Sector

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to control the risk of severe socioecological impacts related to hydrocarbon extraction, enforcement of environmental laws on the part of state agencies is needed. This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate the role of the state in the governance of natural resource extraction by examining the practices of environmental law enforcement in the hydrocarbon sector. The project will contribute to a better understanding of environmental law implementation across time and space as well as the role of the state in influencing the socioecological consequences of resource extraction. It will generate new insights in resource and legal geography by empirically assessing the complex relationships of environmental law enforcement and the role played by the state in the extractive sector. The doctoral student will work with national and regional government agencies, social organizations, and international nongovernment organizations to disseminate project findings. The project will inform policy-makers, government officials, academics, and environmental advocacy groups globally who seek to minimize the negative impacts of hydrocarbon extraction. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The doctoral student will investigate empirically the relationship between institutional capacity, autonomy and the enforcement of environmental laws related to the hydrocarbon sector by taking into account the interplay among the different actors and agencies involved. She will address three core questions: (1) How have increased budgets and regulatory competence led to enhanced autonomy and capacity in the practice of environmental monitoring? (2) What are the conditions under which such institutional changes have translated into successful monitoring of the hydrocarbon sector? (3) How do these processes and patterns vary across space? The student will analyze databases on the institutional capacity and monitoring as well as conflictive and cooperative inter-agency relationships within Ecuador. The analyses should yield a better understanding of the patterns of autonomy, capacity, and monitoring functions of the state agencies as well as enable a comparison of their effectiveness across jurisdictional units.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project studied the role of the state in the governance of resource extraction by examining the practices of environmental law enforcement in the oil and gas sector in Ecuador. The Ecuadorian state underwent a significant re-structuring in 2008, and since then has increased the budget as well as the regulatory competence of its Ministry of Environment significantly.  This project took Ecuador as a case to investigate the conditions for successful environmental law enforcement in the hydrocarbon sector by asking how, and why (or why not) such institutional changes translated into the enforcement of environmental laws in the oil and gas sector on the ground. To answer this question the research project was designed as a comparative analysis of enforcement and state-building practices of the Ministry of Environment at the national and sub-national levels between the years 2005 to 2015. Methodologically, the research project employed the collection and analysis of quantitative and qualitative data, such as interviews, participant observation, official documents, and statistical records. Theoretically, the research projects draw on concepts of the role of state in natural resource extraction by legal and resource geographies, institutional ethnographies of state-making, theories of regulatory enforcement, and theories of the resource curse. Among important results of this research project is the finding that planning documents do matter for the allocation of state-budget to the environmental monitoring of the oil and gas sector.  This is shown by the ranking of environmental variables in budget planning reports being parallel to years in which the programs linked to environmental monitoring of the oil and gas sector at the Ministry of Environment received the most budget. Another important finding suggests that material and behaviour residues of enforcement practices previous to the constitutional change pose considerable challenges to the current enforcement practices as taking away work time that could be better invested in more surprise inspections. And increase in number of surprise inspections would presumably help to reduce further new negative environmental impacts.  The broader impacts of this research project consist, among others, in the dissemination of its finding; which so far consist in five conference talks, and the preparation of three journal articles. Furthermore, the research project generated systematized time-series as well as visual graphs of the budget allocation. Research results will be directly disseminated with stakeholder in Ecuador next summer. One of the main intellectual merits of this project consists in providing more detailed knowledge on the operations of "the state" in the context of natural resource extraction. For instance, it challenges common assumptions of debates on the resource curse by providing evidence that parts of the state budget is allocated to increase state capacity and overall welfare. However, the project also shows that it is important to disaggregate such capacity spatially and sectorial - paying particular attention to "the environment". The research project shows that "the environment” and its protection must take a more central place in debates of the resource curse than it currently does as otherwise the analysis of potentials of developmental transformation through extraction is misguided.  Furthermore, by linking theories of structures and agencies with legal and resource geographies, this the research project demonstrates that explanations for empirical findings can serve as a basis to move from explanations to actual practical support, and conceptualizes a theoretically informed applied geography. The project's intellectual merits on a methodological level consist in providing an example of how to use a mixed-methods approach for studying environmental law enforcement, and combining datasets that were commonly given only little attention in other studies on this topic.
